item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
What is Robotics?

Robotics is a branch of engineering that deals with designing, building and operating robots. It draws on engineering, electronics, and bio-engineering. It is an amazing tool to teach young learners complicated concepts. It provides teachers with an exciting opportunity to inspire, motivate and enlighten young minds.

Why Robotics?

Curiosity is critical to envisioning possibilities! And that is exactly what Robotics does it challenges young children from age 6 on, to develop innovative solutions to challenging technology problems. For example, the young girl in Africa who decided to wrap seeds in damp paper before sowing them to encourage a better harvest or the young man who uses left over solar panels to provide lighting in poor communities.ORT uses Robotics to open minds to learning new skills, harness untapped potential and generate a positive attitude to Maths, Science and Technology.

How ORT uses Robotics

ORT provides a hands-on opportunity to engage practically with this fun exciting initiative. They will work in teams to strategize, design, build, program, test and refine a fully autonomous robotic able to complete a number of missions. Children will experience the thrill of creating something from scratch according to their own ideas while learning to solve problems and overcome obstacles. All the skills needed for successful learning in Maths, Science and Technology. Skills required for successful team work are utilised in all Robotics activities.

item.title: About us
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Vision

With ORT SA CAPE’s diverse educational expertise, we enrich education in impoverished schools and communities focusing on critical educational challenges in Technology, Mathematics and Literacy.

Objectives

To improve the skills of educators by:
  • Fostering professional learning communities for educators in the rural areas of the Western Cape.
  • Facilitating and funding SETA-accredited Grade R teacher training courses.
  • Engaging in research on teachers and learners assessment.
To improve the skills of learners by:
  • Facilitating Constructive Enrichment Afterschool Programmes in rural areas of the Western Cape (CASPER)
  • Facilitating Numeracy, Literacy and Technolgy

Goals

  1. Provide disadvantaged youth/adults with skills and knowledge to cope with their environment; foster economic self-sufficiency, mobility, sense of identity through interventions in Technology, Robotics, Literacy, Science and Mathematics.
  2. Support non-sectarian socio/economic development with vocational training, provision of technical assistance.
  3. Address critical contemporary educational challenges e.g dismal literacy performance on national, international and regional assessments using its capacity and connections.
  4. Undergo regular external evaluation and show measurable, on-the-ground success.
  5. Build strategic partnerships rather than a large employment base.

2013 Strategy

ORT SA CAPE is running the following projects:

A. CASPER: Constructive Afterschool Programme for EnRichment

Creating a safe environment in the impoverished rural areas for children after school, where they would otherwise be left to their own devices. CASPER was launched in July 2012 in 10 schools in disadvantaged areas of Cape Winelands to replace “in class” support due to WCED directive against classroom-based support. Using facilitators we offer young learners reading and writing in home language, and a variety of activities, including Lego programmes, Robotics and Literacy programmes. ORT SA CAPE prepares young learners to understand the basis of critical thinking, as required to succeed in Mathematics and Science, through Robotics.

B.Teacher Training

Grade R SETA Accredited Teachers Training in Overberg, West Coast, Cape Winelands and Metro South since 2009 for Life Skills: Science and Technology. Literacy and Numeracy were added to our offerings in 2012. Current cohorts are 20 Stellenbosch practitioners doing literacy & numeracy [45 credits]; 35 practitioners doing Science & Technology in Metro South. Ort SA Cape’s Grade R Teacher Training Programe is endorsed by Western Cape Education Department (WCED). Mathematics, Literacy and Curriculum Management for School Management Team’s in 10 Stellenbosch Rural Primary Schools which provides professional development for Grade 1 - 7 educators in collaboration with the Universities of Cape Town and Stellenbosch. Stellenbosch provides leadership and management support to all principals and offers support in Maths to 3 of the schools; while UCT provides short courses in Maths (6 schools) and Language (9 schools). ORT provides the after- school reading / writing and resources programme and co-ordinates the programmes.

C. Educational Research and Evaluation

External Evaluation Tender for WCED of Cape Teaching and Leadership Institute (2011/12) learner books analysis, teacher and course evaluation.

item.title: Who we are
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
6.5 million South African children under the age of 6 are deprived of critical early learning opportunities each year, resulting in knock on effects which stack the odds against them throughout their schooling and beyond. For every 100 children entering school, 40 reach and write matric, 28 pass, 4 study further and 1 graduates with a degree in science or technology. We aim to change this. ORT SA Cape works to provide disadvantaged youth and adults with the skills and knowledge required to cope with their environment, foster economic self-sufficiency, and a sense of confidence through exposure to and interventions in Technology, Robotics, Literacy, Science and Mathematics. We support socio-economic development through vocational training and through our expertise and network, we address critical education challenges including the country's shocking literacy performance. ORT SA Cape is proud to be a member of World ORT and a sister organization to ORT SA.

We work to improve the skills of educators by:

  • Fostering professional learning communities for educators, particularly in rural areas of the Western Cape.
  • Facilitating and funding SETA-accredited Grade R teacher training courses.
  • Engaging in research on teachers and learner assessments.

We work to improve the skills of learners by:

  • Facilitating Constructive Enrichment Afterschool Programmes in rural areas of the Western Cape
  • Facilitating Numeracy, Literacy and Technology

What's in a name?

The name 'ORT' was coined from the acronym of the Russian words Obshestvo Remeslenofo Zemledelcheskofo Truda, meaning The Society for Trades and Agricultural Labour. Obviously much has changed since then and today, ORT in our name stands for the Organisation for Research and Training.

The history of ORT

ORT was founded in Russia in 1880 and now has entities in more than 65 countries worldwide working towards the goal of Educating for Life. ORT was founded in South Africa in 1936 as a fundraising entity. In 1994, ORT SA in Gauteng and ORT SA Cape in the Western Cape began to implement programmes aimed at improving education outcomes in the country. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=femMg2JeT6w

Our partners

We are grateful to the incredible men, women and organisations who believe in what we do and make our work possible through their support. {module 93}

item.title: What we do
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
We're serious about seeing education in South Africa improved. We address the challenges in four ways.

1. CASPER

Our Constructive AfterSchool Programme for EnRichment was launched in 2012 as means of creating safe and constructive after-school environments in impoverished rural areas. Using facilitators, we offer learners reading and writing support in their home language along with various activities including Lego programmes, robotics and targeted literacy programmes.

2. Robotics

Robotics is the aspect of our CASPER activities for which we are best known. It is branch of engineering that deals with the design, building and operating of robots. Robotics challenges children from 6 and older to develop innovative solutions to challenging problems. It open minds to learn new skills and harness untapped potential. Through both CASPER and dedicated Robotics Workshops we provide learners with opportunities to engage practically in teams. Children experience the thrill of creating something from scratch according to their own ideas.. All the skills needed for successful learning in Maths, Science and Technology.

3. Teacher Training

Educating and empowering educators is one of the most important things we do. We offer:
  • Grade R SETA-accredited Teachers Training in Science and Technology, Literacy, and Numeracy. This training is endorsed by the Western Cape Education Department
  • Mathematics, Literacy and Curriculum Management for School Management Teams.This training provides professional development for Grade 1 - 7 educators in collaboration with the Universities of Cape Town and Stellenbosch. Stellenbosch provides leadership and management support to all principals and offers support in Mathematics, while UCT provides short courses in Maths (6 schools) and Language (9 schools). ORT SA Cape co-ordinates these programmes while providing the after-school reading, writing and resources programme

4. Educational Research and Evaluation

We specialize in monitoring and evaluation of educational programmes and projects, from learner book analyses to teacher and course evaluation, as an external consultant for the Western Cape Education Department. {module 107}

item.title: Holiday Workshops
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Computer Robotics and Aviation Holiday workshops

at

Iziko South African Museum

For ages 6 to 10 years

A collaboration between Iziko South African Museum, ORT Tech Institute and Sakikhamva

Background

What ORT Tech is doing, is to prepare young learners to understand the basis of the critical thinking, required to succeed in maths and science, through Robotics:

  • Robotics gets young people to use the scientific method of thinking including hypothesising, planning, carrying out the plan effectively and reflecting on it once complete.
  • The use of technology for learning and development is done through the use of Lego Robotics kits used to design and build robots which, besides developing critical thinking, encourages fine motor skills development as well as hand eye co-ordination and auditory listening skills.
  • These kits force learners to follow step-by-step instructions, to work in a methodical and organised way.
  • The workshops are also designed in such a way that children work in teams to achieve an outcome.

All in a thrilling environment that feels nothing like a classroom – it’s fun and stimulating.

We recognise that that these skills can only be acquired over time and that many children are exposed to such experiences in their homes and schools but 85% of this province’s children never get that opportunity.

The October 2011 Holiday Workshop was the second one held. Workshops will be attended by learners from all areas. The intention is that 50% of the intake is sponsored and that 50% have paid for the workshops.

In the true spirit of the ORT philosophy, independence and dignity are the ultimate gift, therefore we undertake to make our project integrated in order for children from all parts of Cape Town to work and play together in a safe and relaxed holiday workshop environment.

While most ORT Tech projects are funded by local companies, they only provide for the minimum basic training and the recession has seen many of these companies drastically reduce their financial support so we need your help. With this in mind, we developed a workshop that is self funding and only required a small percentage of cash donations to make it viable. In kind donations by ORT’s partners Sakikhamva and the IZIKO museum have been invaluable.

item.title: Face the Music Picnic
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Dr Lydia Abel, Director of ORT SA CAPE, addressed our guests. To quote “of every 100 children from disadvantaged backgrounds entering school, 40 wrote Matric, 28 passed and 4 entered university. To put it bluntly, a township child has a 1 in 40 chance of entering a university to study Science and graduating. At the other end of the spectrum, increasing numbers are entering school in Grade R which is essential for later success, but also the number of dropouts by Grade 8 is roughly 30 000 per annum who cannot read and therefore cannot learn.”

Dr Abel continued, “Another educational challenge faces the Grade 7, 8, and 9’s, amongst them potential Engineers, Designers, IT specialists, especially in rural areas where after-school is at best bleak, if not dangerous. Constructive After School Programme for EnRichment (CASPER) aims to provide after school support in the way that so many of our children take for granted. It is a final chance to make a difference at this crucial developmental stage. CASPER provides these budding teenagers with reading, robotics, writing and maths support. I know currently there is a huge emphasis on training for employment, driven by government and the unions – important as that is, the harsh reality is that if we do not get the basics in place early on, there simply will not be any employable people out there to employ”.

Through the phenomenal generosity of our guests, ORT SA CAPE raised the funds required to launch ‘Face the Music’ in Wellington in 2013. ORT SA CAPE makes a difference in the lives of children who have the ability to excel with all the challenges they face on a day to day basis.

item.title: World ORT – Conference in UK 2012
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
This only serves to throw into sharp relief, the dire opposite situation here at home, for the majority of schools and teachers. One has only to look at the Grade 9 results published last month.

One is forced to ask the question: Without a solid foundation, how can learners succeed? Why are learners struggling to achieve higher results?

There has been too much talk of the Matric results. Despite a slight improvement we need to step back and examine why our learners are struggling to achieve the higher results necessary to catapult them into higher education and to become the leaders needed to drive the economy forward. The first five years at school are a ‘make or break’ watershed in a learner’s development and there has been an under-emphasis on education in basic skills such as reading, writing and arithmetic. (Ref: African Education Week, Jan 2012)

The five years before school are just as critical if learners are to develop the essential thinking and learning skills for their further development. Starting from the bottom up is certainly one of the key strategies that must be employed.

ORT-Tech recently amalgamated with ORT Western Cape under the ORT Cape banner, working from David Susman House in Bellville and is now affiliated to ORT SA. With new staff, Debbie Staniland and Lisa Sandler, working alongside Nomfazi Xametshata, Ronel Nel and facilitators Susan Koegelenberg and Pamela Ncapai, it has been possible to set-up and run a range of early learning programmes including Robotics and training for Grade R teachers.

ORT-Tech believes that children's natural curiosity, imagination and creativity are critical qualities to envisioning possibilities and solutions. By encouraging children to explore and develop these qualities in a progressive and positive activity, children learn a positive perception of Science and Technology and how these fields relate to their future. For disadvantaged children, this provides an amazing window into a world they might never otherwise access and gives them the opportunity to acquire the necessary cognitive and comprehension skills for learning, the understanding of how to conduct themselves in a school setting and how to conceptualise and carry out investigations.

Grade R practitioners or teachers are themselves in need of this vital insight and the support to enable them to do this essential job. ORT-Tech has trained more than 300 teachers in disadvantaged schools and centres over the last 3 years. Feedback indicates that the ORTTech Grade R course in Science and Technology impacted positively on teachers’ subject knowledge and classroom practice. It was commended for making complex topics more understandable and thus more easily taught. Lessons became more focused and challenging as learners were seen to be able to engage with scientific and technological concepts through fun activities. Learner behaviour changed for the better. Resource provision and IT training for teachers was a great positive and much appreciated.

Curriculum advisors’ full participation in the courses was an amazing inspiration to the teachers attending and ensured that they knew exactly what was going on as well as ensuring uniformity of delivery from both parties involved. They reported a marked difference in the children coming into Grade 1 from these Grade R teachers’ classes. This is just what we would have anticipated but it is wonderful to have it confirmed.

We are very proud that from our 2011 cohort, Dawn Cozette from Sentinel Primary, in Hout Bay was given the National Grade R Teacher of the Year Award and two teachers from Heideveld Primary (Dale Wyngaard and Lynette Davids) won the Provincial Teacher’s Award for Grade R. Dawn Cozette and Anthea Elliott now run a programme called Home School Partnership, sponsored by Word Works and featured on e.tv under South African Heroes.

item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
ORT SA CAPE’s objective, where possible, uses Science and Technology. In its efforts to achieve its objectives, the organization submits regularly to external evaluations and seeks partnerships with other relevant bodies.

ORT SA CAPE’s Chairman is Simon Susman. The Trustees are D. Resnick, N. Baruch, M. Bagraim, S. Friedman, D. Ginsburg, G. Heneck and A. Kuper. ORT SA CAPE is steered and guided by the passionate and dynamic Dr Lydia Abel, our Director.

ORT SA CAPE launched two new Grade R training programmes, 35 teachers in Metro South (Mitchell’s Plain) Education District and 20 teachers in the Stellenbosch Education District. Our new course has been enhanced to include a language and perceptual skills module.

A very exciting development in the recent past is the implementation of Robotics (LEGO and computers) as a powerful teaching tool. ORT SA CAPE realised that this tool is used all over the world to spark the interest of young and teenage learners in Science and Technology. ORT SA CAPE has coached and empowered teams to participate in the annual FIRST Lego League Robotics competition from 2008.

This year we entered 2 teams for the World Robotics Olympiad on Friday, 20th July at the Cape Town Science Centre. Sihle Eric Hodana, our facilitator, trained the teams during the school holidays. We are very proud that our team was the only team to score in this difficult challenge. The children were so enthused by their results that they went to fetch Eric from his house on Saturday morning, to start preparing for the next competition. Watch this space for their results at the November challenge.

ORT JET will be launching ‘Start your own Business’ series of programmes, run by a Senior Lecturer at UCT. In October the Business Plan Competition 2013 will be launched. ORT JET will also be focusing on Business Support - this programme will focus on providing Cape Town-based businesses with support to ensure financial sustainability and operational viability through a mentor-based philosophy.

Other school based projects we are running include:
ORTSEED Mathematics and Literacy Development in 10 Rural Primary Schools. Currently the focus has been on mathematics with an integrated language and school management support programme. 2012 has seen a collaboration between ORT SA CAPE and Univeristies of Stellenbosch and Cape Town – offering teachers a unique opportunity to engage with each other professionally. I have waited 30 years for this, said one teacher.
Constructive Enrichment Afterschool Programme ( CEAP). Launched July 2012 specifically to replace the “in class” support because of the WCED directive. This programme offers young children multiple opportunities to learn to read and write. A structured programme engaging children with reading primarily through ORT/SHINE Buddy reading methodology, offered in the home language. Children are exposed to a wide variety of activities including robotics, lego programmes and training using cell phone technology to assist with reading and writing stories.This creates a balance beweetn teachers’ development and motivated young children.

Be proud of ORT SA CAPE. It is proud of you!

With thanks to all our generous supporters.

Wishing you all Chag Sameach and well over the Fast.

Dr Lydia Abel and the ORT SA CAPE team

item.title: Are we failing the next generation?
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
What about those children in schools right now? Don’t they also have rights?

Must they wait while teachers play catch up and learners lag up to three years behind?

President Zuma in his state of the nation address asked that civil society plays a role in 'Elevating education to its rightful place' and turning schools into centres of excellence.

ORT SA CAPE is way ahead of him!

CASPER, ORT SA CAPE’s our Afterschool Programme for EnRichment (Reading and Robotics) is already functioning in 18 schools with new programmes planned for Gugulethu and Wellington. We assist young learners to overcome the barriers of not being able to Read to Learn on the one hand, and failing to Learn to Think, on the other. These go hand in hand. Children, who have never experienced mediation by a more knowledgeable older person in an environment conducive to learning, never ever get to learn how to learn.

ORT SA CAPE is creating an afterschool environment in which children feel safe, nurtured and can relax while learning to learn through reading and robotics. This changes attitudes to learning which in turn stimulates teachers to try harder. The nett effect will be more productive, thoughtful students who can take their rightful place building our economy to where it should be.
Productive partnerships have been established with Stellenbosch University, University of Cape Town, Equal Education and Enlighten Trust to extend the reach of our programmes.

ORT SA CAPE needs your help to make the essential service that we provide an ongoing reality.

item.title: CASPER Literacy
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Now available in English and Afrikaans, isiXhosa or isiZulu

Meet the CASPERs

{module 113}  

About the CASPER Literacy Wheel & App

The CASPER Literacy Wheel is an innovative fun, game-like activity where learners can work independently in groups or alone. The aim of the CASPER Literacy is to promote the development of reading with understanding and intentional writing. It has been designed to include Bloom's taxonomy verbs and de Bono's concept of Thinking Hats. Each segment represents a different aspect of thinking and provides Sentence Starters for the relevant questions from Grade 4 upwards. It integrates the key elements of language acquisition and literacy instruction with its focus on the What, Why, When, How, Where and Who. The CASPER Literacy Wheel encompasses all the Thinking Strategies that good readers use to understand text and offers learners multiple opportunities to practice. This frees up the teacher or parent to focus on specific learning issues at any given time and differentiates the classroom. The use of the Wheel and App provides opportunities for teachers to create structured lessons, enabling learners to interact and develop literacy for meaningful communication. The CASPER Literacy Wheel changes the teaching dynamic and assists teachers and learners to make meaning of the text they read and create written text as a result of a well thought through writing process while stimulating thinking and fostering comprehension of what learners read and write.
  • Focuses on comprehension development in reading and writing
  • Motivates guided reading and intentional writing
  • Adapted from paper plate idea (Stricklin, 2011)
  • Combines questions with Bloom's taxonomy verbs and De Bono's Thinking Hats.
  • Each colour represents a different aspect of thinking besides the obvious reading tasks
  • Allows teachers, parents and children to experience meaning of comprehension in a hands-on, practical way.
  • Can be used for fiction as well as academic texts.
  • Helps the learners to make sense of any texts at various levels of engagement through a fun game-like activity.
  • Teacher's role is to activate the thinking processes by creating a learning ambience around the game.
  • Taking slower readers separately for more teacher-directed reading and writing activities, therefore creating the oft touted and remove seldom seen differentiated classroom.

What is the CASPER Literacy Wheel and App?

The CASPER Literacy Wheel and App are tools teachers can use in their classrooms to improve learners' reading practices and to help them become independent readers. It is colour-coded and simple to use. The upper wheel rotates to reveal your chosen segment. You will notice the CASPER App is divided into 8 segments and there are four colours: purple, blue, orange and green. Each colour has two segments, one darker (guiding reading) and one lighter (guiding writing). These two segments are so placed on the CASPER App in order to emphasise the importance of teaching Reading and Writing hand-in-hand, as Reading and Writing should always be connected in the classroom. However, because you will be following only one sequence at a time, (e.g. Reading), you will, of course, skip over the following 'segment' (i.e. Writing) to continue to the next segment. You will also see that there are questions in each segment. It is intended that users of the CASPER App will ask these questions of each other or themselves, when working with fictional or non-fictional texts. Once they feel they have responded to all the questions, they will then turn to the next segment in the series. The CASPER App starts at the purple section. This is Petro the Predictor. The role of Petro is meant to help learners ask important questions BEFORE engaging in the text, about what they expect to read/write and what they already know about the topic. It is known that the better learners are at predicting outcomes and contextualising texts, the more effective Reading and Writing will become. Prediction does not only happen at the start of Reading and Writing: throughout the CASPER App, learners are asked to stop and reflect on what they have predicted, how accurate these predictions have been and then to predict further outcomes based on the evidence so far. Predicting before one begins to read/write is a bit like looking at a map before embarking on a journey: the more one knows about what to expect on a journey, the more exciting the experience as the journey unfolds. After taking on the role of Petro, learners then move on to becoming Charlie the Clarifier. As the name suggests, the role of Charlie helps to make the Reading or Writing clearer, more understandable. Good readers and writers ask themselves clarifying questions before, and while they are reading or writing. Reflections such as, 'I think that the author believes... because' help the reader to make links between the text and his/her own prior knowledge and to make links within the text itself. When writing, learners need to think about how to help their reader/s make these links and to structure their own writing in a clear way. It is advised that learners take on the role of Charlie the Clarifier whenever they come across sections in a text that they are not too sure about. Linked to Charlie is Qhama the Questioner. Qhama has a powerful role because it is Qhama who helps the learners engage meaningfully with the text and to constantly assess what they understand or do not understand. It is in this role that learners engage in higher order thinking by summarising, comparing, critiquing and adjusting. Finally, after having taken on the previous roles during the reading/writing of texts, learners arrive at Sipho the Summariser. It is at this point that learners need to reflect critically on how accurate their earlier predictions have been, what they have learnt, what the experience has meant to them and, in writing, to gauge the quality of what they have achieved.   {module 112}   {module 115}

How to use the CASPER Literacy Wheel & App in a classroom setting

A suggested approach is that learners view the activity as a game, working in groups of 4, and, starting with Petro, move through the various roles, (at their own pace), each one taking a turn to lead the questioning process. However, it is very important that teachers model the use of the CASPER Literacy Wheel beforehand, using strategies like 'think-alouds' to share their own answers to these questions. Equally important is the need for teachers/facilitators to walk around the classroom checking and guiding learners, reminding them to engage fully with each role. They could actually have a competition to design paper hats to represent the different roles. Another way of encouraging learners to take control of their own learning is to set up learning stations (i.e. different tables) where learners engage with a particular role on the wheel and, after a set time, move on to the next table. While it can be a bit chaotic in the beginning, learners quickly learn how to do it efficiently. However, the activity needs to be set up by the teacher beforehand and explained very carefully. Also, when using stations, it is important that learners stick to the set times and pack up the tasks carefully before progressing to the next station. Each station could have its own character flag designed by learners. It should be noted that these particular questions have been selected as prompts towards higher order thinking. Ideally, learners themselves (and teachers) can create their own questions to supplement the enquiry started by the wheel, sparked by the questions used by investigators across the world of Who, What, Why, Where, When, How, which we have included in the centre of the CASPER Literacy Wheel. In summary, this CASPER Literacy Wheel, if used often and correctly, can enable your learners to internalise the reflective process so essential in learning in order to become strong readers and writers. Watch out on the website for more ideas coming soon!

item.dc:creator: charlesmulder

Version 1.0, 1 October 2015 This Privacy Policy explains what Personal Information we collect, how we use it and how we protect it. "Personal Information" means any information that is recognised as such under South African Law and includes any information which identifies you. What Personal Information does ORT SA CAPE collect and how is it used? We only collect Personal Information that is reasonably necessary for us to provide the Application to you.
  • Correspondence information: Information we collect when we receive correspondence from you via email, social media, mobile text messages and phone calls. This includes your sender information, the content of the message and the metadata pertaining to the message. We use this information to communicate with you and to improve the Application.
  • Mobile Application connection information: Your IP address, type, version and language of Internet browser, operating system and version, type of device, screen resolution, referring and exit web pages. We use your IP address to understand the geographic makeup of our customer base and to assist with the identification of potential unauthorised access. We use the rest of this information to optimise the usability of the Application on your access device. We may also compile aggregate information to analyse usage patterns and make improvements to our Application.
Does ORT SA CAPE ever disclose my Personal Information to third parties? We disclose your Personal Information only to our Authorised Service Providers with whom we contract to assist us in providing the Application to you. We may make use of Authorised Service Providers to host and run our servers, send emails, manage support requests and enrich information. They process your Personal Information strictly in accordance with our instructions and for the purpose for which such Personal Information has been disclosed to them. They will always be under obligation to protect your Personal Information on terms that provide the same or equivalent protection as set out in this Privacy Policy. In addition, we may disclose your Personal Information to law enforcement, other government officials, or other third parties as may be necessary in connection with an investigation of fraud, intellectual property infringements, cybercrime or other activity that is illegal or may expose us or our Authorised Application Providers to legal liability. Does ORT SA CAPE use my information for any purpose other than providing the Application to me? We may aggregate and analyse your 'de-identified' information (i.e. stripped of all uniquely identifiable attributes and that cannot subsequently be re-identified) with that of other customers and information received from other sources. We will do this to develop market insights, troubleshoot problems, detect and protect against error, fraud and other criminal activity, identify behaviour/usage patterns and improve our Application generally. We may publish or share the insights we develop through this process. Will ORT SA CAPE ever sell my Personal Information? No. We collect and use your Personal Information only to provide the Application to you and as set out in this Policy. Your Personal Information remains exactly that - yours. How does ORT SA CAPE protect my information? We have implemented reasonable security safeguards to protect the personal information that you provide We use a combination of technical, procedural and operational measures to keep your information safe and secure. Does ORT SA CAPE use Cookies on its website? Unless you have disabled Cookies in your Internet browser, we will store Cookies on your computer/device when you visit our website. These Cookies (small text files containing a string of characters) enable us to recognise you as a returning visitor, track your usage behaviour, as well as store your user preferences and other information. We do this to remember information so that you will not have to re-enter it during your visit or the next time you visit the Website. Cookies also allow us to provide custom, personalised content and information, monitor the effectiveness of our marketing campaigns and monitor aggregate metrics such as total number of visitors and pages viewed. Can I correct my Personal Information? Yes. You are able to correct inaccurate Personal Information via email at info@ortsacape.org.za. We will require that you verify you are in fact the owner of such Personal Information. Once the changes are made we will notify you by email at your nominated email address. If there is any Personal Information not accessible via the Application that you wish to have access to for purposes of correcting, please contact us again at info@ortsacape.org.za. Is my Personal Information deleted when I close my account? Yes. Although there may be some information that we are required by South African law to retain. How long does ORT SA CAPE keep my Personal Information? We will keep your information for as long as you are an active user of the Application. We delete your information when you terminate your use of the Application but will retain some Personal Information for so long as we are obliged to do so under South African law. Such information will always be maintained under the same security and privacy controls that are in place for other customers of the Application. What happens if I wish to opt out of any disclosure of my Personal Information? You may opt out of disclosure of your Personal Information. Should you choose to do this and should the opt out be in respect of Personal Information necessary to provide the Application, we may not be able to continue to provide the Application to you and in such circumstances, we will notify you of this. Should you still wish to opt out after such notification you will be entitled to terminate your use of the Application. What happens if the ownership of ORT SA CAPE changes hands? If we become involved in any merger, consolidation, or sale of our assets and this involves the sharing in any way of your Personal Information, we will let you know before your Personal Information is transferred. Should you not wish for your Personal Information to be so transferred, you may terminate your use of the Application which will result in the deletion of your Personal Information. Who should I contact if I have any comments, questions, concerns or complaints? If you have any questions, comments or concerns about our Privacy Policy, please contact us at info@ortsacape.org.za.

item.title: New robotics clubs launched
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
During July we are launched two more sponsored clubs, one at Salt River Senior Secondary and the other at Thandokhulu High School. The Robotics Clubs at our new venue in the Cape Town Science Centre, contributed to this initiative in partnership with the Western Cape Education Department.

We are excited to be launching the new CASPER project in the Wellington area, with thanks to a generous anonymous donation. This project is held at Berg River High School and includes Robotics and Literacy for 40 high school hostel children.

The children, from our sponsored schools, come from impoverished backgrounds and do not have any intellectually stimulating extramural activities that children who aspire to achieve could benefit from. Our aim through Robotics is to inspire, motivate and enlighten young minds, encouraging a love of learning. These children will become the future engineers and technicians our country so sorely needs!

The CASPER Literacy project is reaching 242 children, in 9 schools, in the Stellenbosch region. Robotics was introduced in May at Lynedoch Primary. The children thoroughly enjoyed the Robotics sessions.

Our CASPER project welcomes community volunteers. Please contact Debbie Staniland at 021 448 8516 for further information.

ORT SA CAPE thanks our donors and friends for their continued support and commitment.

item.title: A holiday of robotics
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Kicking off the activities, students learned about aviation as they raced their newly crafted paper aeroplanes through the museum halls. A first visit for some, the students toured the museum, wowed by dinosaur skeletons and South African nature. Concluding the workshop was a celestial experience from the planetarium.

As a highlight, students worked in pairs, engaged in problem solving and creating complex, functioning LEGO robots. Piecing the LEGO’s together, they were challenged to program the robots themselves. Birds twirled, cars raced and some students even innovated their own operational machines.

With funds raised, ORT SA CAPE was able to sponsor a group of students from Delft for the afternoon sessions, none of whom had ever visited the museum before or touched a computer!

Smiles were infectious as students’ confidence and skills were enhanced throughout the sessions. Proud of their hard work, students left energized and passionate for science and determined to return for another chance to “Robotise”.

Written by Chelsea Bollman, a visiting intern from Michigan State University, studying International Relations, Political Theory & Constitutional Democracy.

item.title: Absa Jewish Achievers Awards speech
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
For the most part, SA children never acquire the critical cognitive and perceptual skills key to problem solving, maths and science but then neither do most teachers.

This is where ORT SA and ORT SA CAPE work for change - we are in the business of opening minds, getting children off the streets into enriching learning experiences like robotics and reading. We balance this with helping teachers to engage with their challenges. Between Cape Town and Johannesburg, we offer multiple learning opportunities to around 24 000 individuals per week including pre-school, in school, post -school learners, teachers, business people and women. Beyond this, we provide a safe, collaborative platform for Jewish people to give back effectively through community outreach.

Skills, job creation, social entrepreneurship - today's buzz words but the harsh reality is that if don't get the basics in place at an early stage there simply wont be any employable people out there to employ and no entrepreneurs to employ them.

I started working in education in 1984 but the last three years at ORT with the generous backing of the Jewish community have been amongst the most rewarding. Thanks to my wonderful colleagues in Cape Town and Johannesburg for always going the extra mile. Thanks to the many involved in this wonderful event.

item.title: Early Childhood Development and ORT SA CAPE’s response to the South African Education Crisis
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
This is where ORT SA CAPE works for change - we are in the business of opening minds, getting children off the streets into enriching experiences like Robotics and Reading. We balance this by helping teachers to engage with their own challenges. With our multiple opportunities to learn, 3000 people over the last 2 years have benefitted from our projects: children and their teachers from Grade R and beyond, as well as post-school youths, business people. Beyond this, we provide a safe, effective platform for people to give back through community outreach.

In addition, we are working tirelessly alongside the Western Cape Education Department to improve the teaching methodologies in 255 Primary Schools and will soon be supporting a similar major project in Limpopo.

We have a long track record of excellence in Teacher Training. While offering our successful Grade R Programme, it became apparent that there was a tremendous need to care for and educate younger children, the 2 to 4 years old.

It is painfully clear that early childhood education is developmentally crucial for children, especially those living in impoverished areas, who are at extreme risk of failing when they get to school for lack of adequate grounding. Current statistics show that South Africa has over 6.5 million children under 6, with about 68% of those aged 4 and below not attending any kind of learning centres, despite an increased enrolment from 158 000 in 1999 to just over 770 000 in 2012/13.

Intervention at this critical stage in a child’s development would vastly improve their success in the future, not to mention their safety. To this end, we have researched possible actions that might be taken by ORT SA CAPE to ensure that this becomes a reality.

The national government recognizes that many Grade R teachers are in effect under-qualified child-minders. Their new plan recently articulated in the Cape Times (Jan 11th 2014) requires more classrooms as well as more suitably qualified and remunerated teachers. The national target for achieving this was set for 2014 but has now been moved to 2019. At best this leaves millions in the care of child-minders! How does this equate with a critical need to address early learning in the first 7 years of life.

Organisations like ORT SA CAPE fill the gap. More than 300 practitioners were trained in the last 3 years – by extension we have reached 1200 children – while a drop in a vast ocean, I am pleased to say that ORT has ensured that we are sending school ready children into the system. Another spinoff of our teacher training is that quite a number of our trainees are now advisors in the department. So yes, they are getting our message!

With your generous support, we will launch a new course, which will properly equip at least 60 child-minders as effective teachers, offering critically needed care for 2-4 year olds. We are currently in negotiations with Herzlia to send their helpers to our training. Other candidates will be from Delft and Cape Flats. Thus previously unqualified people will get a foot on the career ladder to the benefit of their communities and ours.

As you probably realise, all these projects need funding. At ORT SA CAPE we are driving these projects forward with absolute efficiency so that returns on your charitable investment are maximized. We can rest easy knowing that at least some of South Africa’s children have a chance for real education and brighter future.

I must thank my wonderful colleagues and the Board in Cape Town and in Johannesburg for always going the extra mile; Lisa and Cindy for working tirelessly to make today happen - thank you for this wonderful day. And then there are all of you, our funders. While we are affiliated to ORT SA in Johannesburg, we are wholly dependent on Capetonians for our funds. So thank you for your ongoing generosity and support. And to Simon Susman, grateful thanks for always being there!

TOGETHER WE ARE MAKING A DIFFERENCE.

item.title: ORT SA CAPE makes a difference at Berg River High School in Wellington
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
The key of the library was officially handed over to Mr Julies, the Principal of Berg River High in February 2014. He expressed his gratitude for ORT SA CAPE’s involvement at his school with special mention for all the books donated to establish the long awaited library. A comfortable quiet space has now been created for learners to develop a love for reading and studying. The Wellington Librarian, Elsabe Du Toit, trained two young local women to run the library, which is open 5 days a week, thereby creating 2 brand new jobs in this rural area where jobs are scarce.

ORT SA CAPE also offers the following programmes being run by local students from CPUT at Berg River High School:

  • The Robotics Programme runs 3 times a week for the top 20 Maths and Science students in Grade 9; Grade 8 will also be included in this programme shortly.
  • The Reading Programme, which includes 25 learners from the hostel, focuses on developing fluency, understanding and the love for reading. The learners especially enjoy reading on iPads.
  • A Drama Programme gives much joy to 30 learners. Apart from gaining confidence, developing their voice, creativity and communication skills, these learners are currently writing their own plays about conflicts in their community.

item.title: Robotics Holiday Workshop | April 2014
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Our Robotics Centre was open every day and we had a regular stream of children who wanted to learn more about Robotics.

At the 3 day holiday workshop we had sponsored groups from Ngamana Safe Home Academy (NGAMSHA) and Hope 4 Destiny, an NGO based in Delft. A total of 36 children from Hope 4 Destiny joined us for a full programme that included a lesson on aviation presented by Fatima Jakoet from the Sakhikamva Foundation, a guided tour through the National Museum and a planetarium visit. The children were equally as engrossed with building and programming their robots as they were when they were quietly absorbed reading stories or doing interactive puzzles on the iPads.

One of our challenges organising activities for children remains safe and reliable transport to and from the venue. Despite this the children still managed to arrive with their facilitators using hired and public transport.

We would like to thank our partners the Sakhikamva Foundation and Iziko Museums for making this workshop possible and creating an event that was both educational and memorable for the children.

item.title: ORT SA CAPE’s Innovative Educational Tool is launched
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
The CASPER Reading Wheel is being piloted at nine rural Primary Schools and one High School in the Cape Winelands. The reaction of the children is one of excitement, the same as when they discover a new board game. Children are having fun while using the four strategies of predicting, clarifying, questioning and summarizing their work.

“There is a quietness and concentration when they are answering the ‘During Writing’ questions – they even cover their work so they don’t all write the same things. And then there is such excitement when it’s the Summarisers turn – they just can’t wait. After a time, they start to remember some of the questions and are bursting to answer.”
Quote from Anne Pietersen, ORT SA CAPE Facilitator

Positive outcomes and benefits of the CASPER Comprehesion Wheel:

  • Promotes interaction and discussion through questions.
  • The strategic use of asking questions explicit to facilitators, volunteers and learners.
  • It provides a routine that helps learners to make connections and enables the facilitator and volunteer to be more efficient.
  • It scaffolds think-aloud for teachers and students.
  • It helps all readers to comprehend better.

No better way for children to learn while having fun!

“The kids are instantly enthralled by Lego Robotics, and they soon discover that the only way they can build them is by reading the ‘how to’ program. And suddenly, it’s all they want to do,” says Dr Abel. Robotics is a branch of engineering that deals with designing, building and operating robots. It draws on engineering, electronics and bio-engineering and is an amazing tool to teach young learners complicated concepts. It provides teachers with an exciting opportunity to inspire, motivate and enlighten young minds.

ORT SA CAPE receives regular calls from principals of the schools involved, reporting a massive improvement in the participants overall behaviours. The children’s self-esteem improves, they start asking questions, getting the work done and best of all they start helping their peers.

The organisation also fosters learning communities for teachers in the rural and urban areas of the Western Cape; these include facilitating and funding SETA-accredited Grade R and Early Childhood Development Teacher Training Courses.

Fifty adults fulfilled their 67 minutes and more in the spirit of Mandela Day. They helped the children explore and engaged with them directly on all the activities.

item.title: FLL 2014 – First Class Performance
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
The FLL has three parts: Core Values (teamwork), the Project (an intense research and design project) and the Robot Game (where they design, build and program a Lego Mindstorms robot to score points on a timed course). Each of these sections are equally important to success, and all require dedication.

For ORT SA CAPE, the competition is even more exciting as it enables us to expose underprivileged children to a whole new aspect of life, one where they control their future directly, and where their rewards are entirely dependent on their input. We use the event to build into their education, character and future while teaching them to appreciate the value of their own work. Last year we entered 6 teams, three of which I was personally involved with, and two of which I coached. One of these teams, the RoboNovas, amazed us all by coming third in the Western Cape and winning the National Trophy for Excellence in Programming.

The RoboNovas are a team of four home schooled boys who had known each other for a few months before the competition. Caleb (11) and Sam (9) were brothers who had worked on the older generation of robots for a few months prior to the competition, whereas Josh and Christian (both 10) were recent friends who had just joined our home schoolers club. They had no experience with the current generation of Mindstorms, the EV3, which is the robotics platform used to compete. They had a passion for learning and a yearning to test their ability against tried and tested teams with the age and experience advantage.

The parents ran the research side of the project on their own time, while we handled the robotics. At least twice a week, for three months, these children came to our facilities to learn and practice. For the first one and a half months we just focused on learning, getting them up to speed with the programming, the hardware and the rules. Right from the get-go we were able to see who preferred to build, who would rather program and who loved the strategy side.

Leading up to the competition we battled with keeping all the teams up to speed, but the RoboNovas refused to crack under pressure. It was amazing to watch these 10 year old children set aside their personal pride in the name of the greater good, accepting the notion that their idea may not be the best, or that someone else was better in a certain area. They learnt to cope with each other, and defied the disadvantage their age and schedules provided. While other teams were able to meet almost daily, and had the equipment at their home, our teams were only able to practice at the office when they could all meet up with a facilitator.

On the day of the competition they were still programming the robot to do new challenges, instead of fine tuning well established code like the other teams. It paid off, and they came third out of 30 teams in the Western Cape and qualifying them for the National Leg in Joburg. They scored in the top ten in the Robot Game and won a trophy for Project Innovation for their educational computer game they designed and programmed to teach children how to eat healthily.

Despite the ecstasy of 3rd place, we found ourselves under pressure to send a team of children across the country with less than a month's notice. We scraped together the funding, receiving generous help from Protea Hotels, as well as our personal contributions to make this chance a reality.

We flew up, and our little troopers were too excited to be nervous. Their hard work had paid off, and they were going to show the judges that they were no pushovers. Because we weren't able to bring our store of Lego with us, and the Gauteng teams had been able to practice without pause since the Regionals, we were once again on the back foot. Over the two day event we split our time between coding new missions, practicing old ones, interacting with other team and exploring the wonderful venue (the Sci-Bono Centre). Nerves ran rampant among child and adult alike, tempered only by anticipation.

The children wowed the judges once again, and displayed the most blatant honesty I've ever seen from a child. The judges seemed to doubt that children so young had done such complex coding and detailed research, leading them to lay traps for the team with questions. The kids fearlessly displayed even more knowledge and understanding of their topics than they had in the presentation, going so far as to unintentionally sass the judges by giving him their average age to show that they grasped the concept and maths behind averages (which they used heavily in their code).

Despite not qualifying for the International Leg, our boys won the Trophy for Excellence in Programming, and won the adoration of the teams for their unbridled enthusiasm, young age and pure spirits. They have proven to be fast learners and excellent sportsmen, and are waiting with bated breath for the FLL in 2015.

The whole experience allowed ORT SA CAPE to change the lives of four families, and set an example of hard work and dedication to other teams. It grew us as much as it grew them, and I think it's fair to say that we are just as eager as they are for Round 2.

item.title: What people ORT to do
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
The local branch of this venerable organisation runs projects in teacher empowerment, new venture creation and enterprise, and skills development in some of the country's most disadvantaged communities.

"I am extremely grateful for this opportunity to visit South Africa," said World ORT chairperson Dr Jean de Gunzburg.

"The pride of ORT all over the world is that its graduates [children, youth and adults] are taught skills specifically for the present-day job requirements. Agriculture and trades were taught by ORT 100 years ago, and today, robotics, bio-technology and other new innovative skills are taught."

Participants were treated to a demonstration of ORT's work in South Africa's schools when two Grade 7 pupils of Ikage Primary School, Alexandra, performed a dialogue about how ORT helped them improve their marks. Ikage is one school in which ORT runs its successful teacher empowerment programme, providing classroom-based support in maths and science.

During the course of their visit, the World ORT committee members visited two more schools in Alexandra, where they were treated to a demonstration of mathematical skills by Grade 1 pupils.

Naomi Xashimba, an Alexandra teacher of 35 years said, "Besides the weekly training of teachers, if we have a problem we just call the ORT SA team and they come out immediately to assist. The laptops that we received through Bidvest were the best thing to happen to us."

ORT South Africa chief executive officer Arriellah Rosenberg, meanwhile, explained the value of ORT's international co-operation.

"World ORT is one of the largest NGOs globally in skills and vocational training, and a leader in high-tech education and training. The interest they have shown in ORT SA bodes well for our future expansion and potential collaboration with corporates and governments," she said.

Written by a Staff Reporter of the North Eastern Tribune

item.title: Overview of our projects 2014/2015
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Teacher Training

Training of Curriculum specialists in Limpopo in conjunction with Deloitte and Touche

ORT SA CAPE has been appointed by Deloitte as Literacy specialists to train and develop Curriculum specialists and Educators in Limpopo. 119 schools have been identified in the province to participate in a three year 'school turn-around' programme. The focus will be on training the educators in Cognitive and Perceptual Skills as well as concentrating on literacy and comprehension development. Dr Lydia Abel & Karen Kaimowitz spent a day in Polokwane introducing concepts to the Curriculum specialists, district and circuit managers.

Level 4 Early Childhood Development Training for Herzlia & Phyllis Jowell teacher assistants

February saw the start of our much anticipated Early Childhood Development (ECD) Teacher Training Course for 35 classroom assistants from Herzlia and Phyllis Jowell. The eager and dedicated ECD practitioners arrived at the training with much excitement and a willingness to learn more, embarking on the first step to a Tertiary Education Qualification. The course is a Level 4 SETA accredited qualification through Boland College and students will attend classes at the Cape Town Science Centre once a week over an 18 month period. Classes are presented by ORT SA CAPE's highly qualified and competent facilitators. The funding for this training enables us to offer a follow up course to potential ECD facilitators from the Cape districts.

Emergent Mathematics Training for Grade R Educators

ORT SA CAPE was awarded the tender by WCED Metro South to train 30 Grade R educators in Emergent Mathematics. The 70 hour course covered appropriate Mathematics concepts, e.g. measurement, pattern, shape, numbers and data handling) from September 2014 – February 2015. This training culminated in a 2 day EXPO where educators showcased their resources and knowledge gained on the course. The EXPO was attended by school principals, curriculum advisors and Metro South Management.

A Partnership with National Association for Childcare Workers

A training conference for 100 childcare workers from 224 Centres and Safeparks nationally was held in Durban on 19-21 September 2014. Training was offered in Maths, Literacy development, Perceptual skills and Robotics. The feedback was immensely positive with all participants saying not only were they educated but also energised.

Constructive After School for EnRichment (CASPER)

Winelands Reading and Robotics

ORT SA CAPE has secured a partnership with University of Stellenbosch involving the Social Work and Engineering Faculties. Robotics training includes aspects of Technology linking the subject to the current curriculum. 10 Stellenbosch schools and 3 Wellington schools are involved in the CASPER Winelands projects. A new partnership is emerging in Franschhoek which will bring 5 more schools on board. More than 500 children will be involved in the Reading and Robotics CASPER project this year. The Berg Rivier Secondary School Drama group in Wellington wrote and produced an original play which won first prize at the Wellington Arts Festival. Currently 344 children are attending CASPER in the Winelands, facilitated by 126 University students.

Urban Reading and Robotics

The Casual Walk-Ins, School Holiday Workshops, Robotics for Home schoolers, Weekend Robotics Clubs and School Extra Mural Clubs continue to draw large numbers. Currently over 250 children benefit from these programmes. The Bamphumelele Orphanage project is running successfully and the M&E indicates that children are improving in reading, comprehension, concentration and writing as well as finding the robotics stimulating. 6 robotics teams entered the FLL competition with one of our teams taking third place at nationals.

Research: Monitoring and Evaluation

ORT SA CAPE is approaching the final months of the 2013/2014 tender to evaluate the Literacy and Numeracy Intervention of the Western Cape Education Department. The project is proceeding as planned and well within budget. It is being well received with positive and encouraging feedback. A bid for the next 2016/2017 WCED Lit Num tender has been submitted by ORT SA CAPE. We are awaiting the confirmation of the service provider, which will be announced by the WCED in April 2015.

Events

Annual Fundraiser luncheon: Sunday 15th March, our annual picnic fundraiser was held at Klein Cabriere, in Franschhoek. Another successful event raising funds for our Constructive After school Programme for EnRichment. 2015 Cape Town Cycle Tour: ORT SA CAPE was approved as a charity for the 2015 Cape Town Cycle Tour, 50 supporters cycled to raise money for ORT SA CAPE. Grade R Teacher Graduation 18th August: Held at the Cape Town Science Centre 46 teachers received certificates. Mandela Day Celebrations 2014: 91 children from Delft and Khayelitsha orphanages enjoyed a day of Robotics and Science Centre activities with ORT SA CAPE, M&C Saatchi Abel, Deloitte & Touche at the CTSC.

Innovations

ORT SA CAPE's CASPER Literacy Wheel has been well received. UCT Schools Development Unit is using the wheel in their training programmes and Deloitte for language development training Grade 4 -12. As a result of the World ORT visit, we are digitising the wheel into an app.

ORT JET

Through the mentorship programme, monthly networking events and training ORT JET is successfully fulfilling a need to support small Jewish businesses in the Cape Town. Currently 51 businesses are on the Mentorship Programme. ORTJET Networking events are supported on average by 20 businesses. Training sessions for both mentors and mentees are run through Deloitte Cape Town. Regular feedback forums are held for mentors and businesses.

item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
{gallery /}

My passion for the intersection of technology and education aligned perfectly with the mission of ORT SA CAPE, which strives to offer educational enrichment to children and teachers in impoverished schools and communities through reading and robotics. For my honours thesis in Computer Science, advised by Dr. Orit Shaer, I studied how commercially available tangible technology toys, such as littleBits and KIBO, can promote the development of computational thinking for children in early elementary school. At Wellesley, I also taught programming classes, led robotics workshops, and hosted a weekly "Girls Who Code" club for children in the local area. I was thrilled about the opportunity to do similar things in Cape Town, which started from a Friday night dinner conversation between Dr. Orit Shaer and Tracey Frankel.

While here, I have particularly enjoyed hosting two Girls in Action workshops with ORT SA CAPE. Even in the States, there is a huge gender gap in the technology industry; too many young girls are either discouraged from studying technology-related fields or are never given the opportunity to discover the technology world. It is true here in Cape Town too, and it's amazing to watch the workshop participants explore and learn together. As one 10-year old girl said at the end of our two-hour workshop, "Sometimes I thought that it was very hard to put things together, but it's actually quite easy."

{gallery /}

In addition to encouraging more girls to pursue robotics and technology, I have also been working to integrate littleBits into ORT SA CAPE's robotics activities. littleBits, magnetic modules that snap together to create electronic circuits, are an exciting new toy that can help children learn sequencing. They also foster children's ability to develop fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination, which can positively impact their self-esteem and ability to read.

It has been incredible to live and work in this beautiful city. In meeting children, parents, teachers, and other locals. I have learned so much about the history, culture, and nature here. The poverty is beyond heart breaking, but the views are breath taking - to read more about my journey and see photos, feel free to follow my blog: cs.wellesley.edu/~vlin/wp/blog/.

Veronica Lin
Wellesley College | Class of 2015
Computer Science & Economics Major

item.title: NACCW ECD training
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
Each mentor returned to their respective communities to train and support other child and youth care workers using their new knowledge and kits filled with toys and educational resources provided by ORT SA CAPE. The childcare workers visit and work with children, parents and caregivers in individual homes and teach groups in the 'Safe Parks' to allow children access to education.

Our training assisted them with understanding child development, the appropriate use of toys for this purpose and providing appropriate educational stimulation using both commercially available and recycled resources. Another highlight of the training was the introduction of teaching science and emergent maths in the Early Childhood Development (ECD) environment.

A big thank you to our generous donors and suppliers who assisted us to provide this opportunity.

item.title: Western Cape schools compete in drama competition
item.dc:creator: charlesmulder
item.content:encoded:
{gallery /}

Bergrivier Secondary School will perform the play Map Jacobs by Adam Small. This play is one of their prescribed set works for the year. This follows on from their success at the competition last year where they were awarded four silver and many bronze awards.

This year, Plankies, a play written by Bergrivier Secondary School grade 12 learner Neville Albertus, will be adjudicated in the category of best new scripts and the winner will be announced at the National ATKV tienertoneelkompetisie at Aardklop Potchefstroom in September.

Both Wellington and Bergrivier Secondary Schools are able to attend the Port Elizabeth competition due to the support and encouragement of local NGO, ORT SA Cape, which focuses on enriched learning experiences for children and training for teachers.

"We financed the support of the two drama groups as part of our after school programme (CASPER - Constructive After School Programme for EnRichment)," explains Dr Lydia Abel, Director of ORT SA Cape.

"In recent years there has been a global move to include Arts in the strategic focus areas of STEM (science, technology, engineering and maths) to make it STEAM. US research indicates that involvement with arts helps children to think creatively, encouraging them to learn to read and speak in public."

"We would love to make support for impoverished schools wanting to partake in this competition an annual reality. We encourage those who love the arts and are willing to contribute in some way, to contact us."
